description:
Honestly, I haven't Yelped in years, but I really wanted to highlight this restaurant.  Husband and I had walked by dozens of times, and finally decided to give it a try tonight.  The food hit all the right notes, and was totally different from what you'd find at a typical Indian restaurant.  Really surprising was how well it every single dish went with a dry Macedonian rose that we picked out--you usually think of beers with Indian food.  We got the peanuts, bhel puri, lentil pancakes, and potato burgers.

Can't wait to go back and try some of the other wines, and we're already regretting all the times we walked by without stopping in!
author: Sam M.

description:
Quiet place
Good food
Fine wine
Indian dhaba feels
Don't expect too much it's quick hangout spot types!
author: Surya V.

description:
We were looking for a fun and different place to catch a light meal and wine before a concert and came acros across the Indian Paradox on Divisidaro. 

Food: The food is small-plate Indian "street food" with mostly vegan choices and one lamb dish. We tried 4 of the selections and they were all very fun and tasty, especially the little potato "sliders". Not a full meal of course but perfect with a glass of wine from their limited but interesting international selection. Score: A-

Atmophere: Casual and Indian-color-washed, perfect compliment to the street food. Could use some new (less wobbly) tables which we were told were coming soon. Score: B

Service: Not crowded when we were there but the service was super friendly, fast and helpful. Score: A

 Value: About average value for this sort of place. You get what you pay for. Score: B+

Reccomdended!
author: Vince C.

description: This is a great place for classy indian street food. I usually get the Dabeli (to die for), bhel puri, and dahi sev puri. The Dabelis are really well made and have a mix of salty and sweet flavors. I would also recommend getting the sweet wine they have on their menu - it works well with all the food!
author: Sonali G.

description:
I'm not sold on the pairings here, or the menu. Poha with wine? But why? Chai or kapi, sure, but wine with that? Also, sundal? I have some trouble eating something that I receive as a blessing at the temple with wine, forgive my upbringing. I don't disagree with the concept offhand - Indian food and wine can and should be paired, but it has to be the right food with the right wine. Indian home-style tiffin food or simple chaats are hard to find in SF and I appreciate the effort to bring them some notoriety, but I left unconvinced that these dishes are those that go best with wine.  

Just a note re: our experience: It's off-putting when a non-Indian waiter tries to explain Indian food to Indian customers without being asked. Often times we come to the restaurant because we know the food, and its presence in a restaurant intrigues us. So we know what it is we are asking to eat, so having someone who can't quite even pronounce a dish name properly tell us what we'd want to eat, and how to eat it, is disconcerting to say the least.

All of this said, the food was pretty tasty, and others in my group would come again. As for me, I think I'd wait until the menu lives up to the promise of the restaurant's premise - Indian food that actually pairs well with wine.
author: Archana P.

description: The poha was excellent and just what I needed one fine evening ! The sev puri wasn't exactly authentic but it tasted good.
author: Ankita U.

description: I wasn't completely convinced with the food or the wine pairings here. The Indian food was not fusion or authentic, it kind of all just tasted average. Super small place and the service was definitely average. The happy hour menu is unclear as it seems like it's just smaller portions of the main menu. Was not impressed
author: Ruchi M.

description: I have been here 3 times now. I love the food. It's Indian street food done to perfection. I have tried peanuts, Dahi Puri, dabeli, pho's and kebabs. Love the selection of wines. Grab a window seat and talk for hours with a friend. Hostess very friendly. Location is awesome. Classy and delicious. Going back again this Friday with another friend. Just one request please serve masala chai in the evenings too.
author: Dr. Manisha Punwani, M D.

description:
Savory food, cozy, good wine, and the lady who works here is a gem. 

Get a simple snack and wine and see where it goes. You'll be fine.
author: Harjot H.

description:
This was a cozy Indian tapas restaurant with a clean and light menu. The server/owner was really nice and attentive. Everything was labeled for vegetarian/vegan and gluten-free items, so score for the heath nuts! We got the chickpea salad, the potato burger, and lamb kabab. 

It's tapas, so portions are small, typical pricing for tapas - so don't come here looking for a deal. If you come during happy hour, the happy hour items are 1/2 portion of the regular menu. We got confused since my bf and I were looking at the same items, but he was looking at a blue menu, and I was looking at a green menu - one of those was happy hour and the other was not. So when he ordered, it must've been off the happy hour menu, because we were both surprised... and still hungry... but had somewhere to be so we couldn't wait to order more food. 

Were we the only ones confused? Maybe make it easier for the easily confused like us...... por favor!
author: Maymie C.

description: Went here last night for just a weeknight dinner. Was prefect. Nice cosy spot with lots of unique Chaat options. Its not easy to find the options they have at any other place, namely Sundal, poha and Adai. Would be perfect if they started chai too. I am definitely going here again.
author: Rutika D.

description: Neat little spot with good Chaat (Indian light snack) and excellent wine pairing. Recommend getting the recommended rose with the Bhel Puri Chaat.
author: Karan S.

description:
Really cool, funky place -- great for Indian small plates. Started off the meal with a Madras coffee -- super delicious, a perfect amount of sweetness. Shared a dosa and green chili cheese bread with my friend. 

Dosa: You get two small dosas, spiced potatoes, and two types of chutney. The red one had a nice kick to it. The potatoes were nicely spiced. Doesn't come with sambar
good, tasted homemade and the red chutney was so good. Didn't come with sambar though.

Green chili cheese toast: So DELICIOUS... I've never had something like that before. My friend was excited about it since it reminded her about her Mumbai days. Came with some sauce (it tasted like the sweet/spicy maggi sauce)... so cheesy and soo good. It went with well with the red chutney from the dosa plate.  

The portions are a bit small so be prepared to order a little extra if you're really hungry.
author: Sarah S.

description:
What a gem! Quaint, intimate, Indian tapas place with a great happy hour menu (5-7pm, 50% off select chaats). Perfect if you love trying different dishes, in this case, various Indian street foods. Great wine list as well. I love the extra touch of detail in including a wine pairing recommendation for each menu item. The two of us came in around 6:30pm on a Tuesday and were seated right away. We ordered the Sundal, the Sev Puri, the Dabeli, and the Shish Kebab. All the dishes were delicious. 

SUNDAL -- A good way to start the meal. I loved the extra crunch from the mustard seeds and the mango added a nice touch of sweetness.
DAHI SEV PURI -- MUST TRY. These bite-sized puffs were so fun and unique. They were literally an explosion of flavor and the perfect texture too.
DABELI -- MUST TRY. Another unique one. I loved the pomegranate and spicy peanuts in the "patty" and overall, the flavor was great.
SHISH KEBAB -- The lamb was SO juicy. Each bite was perfect with a sliver or two of onion and some chutney.
MISHTI DOI -- A good way to end the meal and a must try for any pistachio lovers.

Overall, a very well-rounded meal. Happy stomachs + happy wallets = happy people. I can't wait to come back and try other chaats. The owner was very attentive and her passion for wine and food truly shined through. This was a different and refreshing dining experience and I urge everyone to come experience the Indian Paradox.
author: Lydia K.

description:
This place is such a refreshment in the midst of the other Indian restaurant that are just trying to sell you the same Paneer / chicken curry with Naan.

We tried Dahi Puri, churmura (which is broken Pani Puri), Adai (protein Dosa), Dabeli and ended with Mishti Doi which was my favorite.

Each and every dish was carefully served and explained. Ambience was good a bit tiny but if you found a seat then who cares. Absolutely loved this place!
author: Sanat T.

description:
Indian tapas place that's great for dates /small groups of friends! Not your typical Indian curries either- it's "street food" paired with wine hence the paradox in the name.

Came here for dinner with a friend on a Friday night around 7:40 pm! It looked small when we first arrived at the door but it doesn't feel crammed- more like an intimate ambience good for dates or a cozy one for when the weather is cold out.  

My friend and I ordered the following: 
-Adai ($14) : described as "protein savory pancake" on their menu, made from 4 different lentils, rice,cumin, curry leaves, chilies. Came out nice and warm after about 15 minutes of waiting. The pancake itself isn't actually overly flavorful- it's simple. The coconut chutney that comes with it is what provides that nice contrast, bringing out the cumin/curry flavors of the pancake itself. For all non-coconut fans out there, it's worth noting that the chutney isn't too coconut-y or over the top, or at least balanced with the pancake it's worth trying. Overall, 4/5- it was good but I wasn't dying to eat like 10 more after. 

-Sundal ($7) a warm garbanzo bean salad with curry leaves/ coconut/ mustard seeds/ mango. Sounds like an interesting mashup of ingredients but it's very good! Really liked the sweetness of the mango, contrasted with the crunchy  mustard seeds. Big fan and highly recommend getting (especially if you like chickpeas!) 4.5/5

Service - We had to wait awhile (40min) for the Sundal because there was some sort of mix up in the kitchen, but the owner was really nice (she's the only one waiting tables) and took it off of our bill. :) its not heavily staffed in the kitchen, and the owner is the only working the front, so might not be great if you're in a hurry but service is good and the owner is friendly and nice.

Recommend if you're trying to try something new for a date or catch-up with a friend!
author: Kristie M.

description:
Really good hole in the wall Indian street food restaurant. Went there for brunch and had poha, chilly cheese toast, Keema, tea, coffee and wine

Everything was delicious, liked pairing wine with Indian food. Would definitely come back
author: Saurabh M.

description:
Perfect place for Indian tapas paired with wine. This is a cute spot for dates. Friday nights are usually busy. 
Kavitha is very hospitable and I have thoroughly enjoyed her recommendations for food-wine pairing! The sundal, bhel puri and adai are so authentic, they remind me of home.
author: Poornima S.

description:
Street food Taste likes made from scratch n high quality. No food color no corn syrup. Adai is homestyle. Great for vegan and vegetarians! 

Only non commercial chaat in SF. I have tried all top rated Indian ( n street ) food - chat corner, amber, dosa, vicks chaat(berkeley), etc. 

Only thing- dabeli  is missing tamarind n garlic chutney.
author: chess t.

description: Went for brunch which was a paradox, both unique and unmemorable. The restaurant is an intimate size, distinctively small yet a bit drab. The restaurant is the right size for a table of two but would be tough for a part larger than four. The lemongrass chai is delicious and the menu features many dishes that may not be very familiar to anyone who hasn't had many Indian breakfasts.
author: Lauren B.

description:
We love this place. Probably been here 10 times by now. The food is fantastic and consistent, and clearly very fresh out of the kitchen every time we come.

The owner Kavitha has created a fun, personal, inviting atmosphere. We never have a problem bringing a group of 4 in here for a bigger meal or just coming for a quick bite. The staff is always nice and accommodating. 

Being a vegetarian, it's always great when a place has lots of options, but at Indian Paradox most of the items are vegetarian, which is one of the reasons we keep coming back. The food is delicious. The wine is amazing. As you can tell we love this place. It's a staple for us now and we're so glad it's in NOPA.
author: Ian A.

description: Great Indian snacks. A little pricey but definitely worth trying. Service is great. Wine pairings were amazing as well.
author: Naresh M.

description: I came here the other night with some friends and it's a rather small space so we had to pull 2/6 of the available tables together for 4 people but I have to say, space restrictions aside, the food is phenomenal. I've never paired indian street food with wine before and it was an excellent decision. The food itself is so tasteful and we went with the bartender's wine pairing instead of the commonly applied one. Great experience, cannot wait to come back! Oh and the service was tremendous as well!
author: Tania S.

description: The woman serving was awesome! The restaurant is super small, it's hot or too cold inside and someone was cleaning in the back (which is literally a few feet from the tables) and the cleaner was up our noses while we were eating!!! The food was definitely good. The ambience - ugh/just not worth the price-  expensive for the amount of food- In the end: so so so many amazing restaurants in this town better.
author: E S.

description:
Portions are really small for the price. We got the shish kebab ($18) and agai ($12) and both good but tiny. I left feeling really hungry still, and probably wouldn't return.
Service was really friendly though.
author: Maggie L.

description:
I love this place!  Growing up in so-cal, I was missing the quality of the chaat and Indian food I got near home.  I came here and finally found a place that lives up to my high bar!  And Kavitha is always so nice and remembers us every time we come, asking about my family, niece, etc.  She's great and so wonderful to chat with!  

We've ordered pretty much everything vegetarian on the menu and  enjoyed our meals!  We always ask to make the dishes spicy to accommodate our taste and absolutely love the churmur, dahi sev puri, and dabeli!  We've brought several guests who have all enjoyed it and even tried to bring our parents, but failed to realize they were closed for the holidays.  Next time!  Now, we're excited to come back and try the new brunch menu!  Definitely recommend eating here!
author: Rachana S.

description:
This restaurant is a gem. It has a small and quiet ambiance and is the perfect spot to have a conversation over flavorful Indian dishes and beautifully paired wines. 

You will not find the typical chicken tikka masala and naan here- the food is unique, homemade, and was clearly thoughtfully made. The lamb kebab was excellent, and so was the (blanking on the name) vegetarian potato burger with homemade bread. 

There are many vegetarian options and 2 lamb options. We will be recommending this place to friends and will be back! I'd love to try everything on the menu :)
author: Leeyen R.

description: Loved this little wine bar on divisadero! They serve Indian street food (or chaat, as we call it) so don't expect any chicken tikka masala, korma or naan. Instead order the dahi sev puri (delicious), the dabeli (the bread on this potato "burger" is soft and buttery perfection) or even the lamb seekh kebab. Major plus points for their super authentic masala chai and selling Indian soda (Thums Up). Next time I go here I'll try the wine combos for sure!
author: Sam M.

description: Amazing Indian street food. You get things here that you don't find anywhere easily else like sundal, poha etc.
author: Srinivas N.

description:
One of the most lovely places I've been to in a long time. The woman helping us (forgot her name, my apologies) was so kind and helped us with our food and wine pairing. 

First, the wine was out of this world. She suggested the wine that was on special (not many places do this!) and brought us two glasses. Much needed on a Tuesday evening. 

The food...so great. I loved everything. The tip is to come during happy hour (ends at 7) and you can try their hit items. 
I really loved this place and it made me love San Francisco restaurants again. I thought we were going to be stuck with overpriced, mediocre wait-in-line types. 
This restored my faith! A must visit :)
author: Annie C.

description:
When dining out, I like to try anything AND everything. However, I will never eat moth larvae tacos or beef brains again. Both times, I ended up hugging Mr. Kohler from both ends for a week. That's what I get for trying to all adventurous and shiet like Andrew Zimmern.

My friend said, "Think of it as a FREE detox, you now don't have to spend $150 on those yuppie juices". Yah, but that $150 went to Charmin. =/  

I read about the opening of Indian Paradox on Tablehopper. The owner came to the U.S. to pursue a degree in mechanical engineering but soon developed a passion for wine (she's now a certified sommelier). She also loves Indian street food so Indian Paradox was born. It started as a pop-up and is now a wine bar serving Indian street snacks at the former King Food Subs (RIP Kalbi sammies). I saw a glimpse of the soft opening menu which looked foreign to me. SOLD! None of that yipsterfied ethnic food.

My friend and I visited Indian Paradox on Saturday night. It was inconspicuous as there's no signage so I had to take a double take before realizing we were at the right spot. It's a very small space with just 4 tables and bar seating so it's best suited for solo dining or for a casual date. 

The vegetarian and vegan friendly menu is small with only 10 items split up into 4 categories: wine nibble (peanuts), street snacks (sundal, churmur, methi muthia, bhel puri), plates (khanda batata poha, dahi sev puri), and more substantial platters (daebli, shish kebab, kheema pav). With exception of two things, I've never seen any of these items anywhere else in San Francisco. Nothing is over $20. Each item had a suggested wine pairing ($10-$15/glass) which we skipped since we both had been drinking earlier and had to drive. 

Since it was our second dinner of the night, we shared 3 street snacks/small plates:
*Bhel Puri: Crispy crackers, puffed rice, jaggery, mint chutneys, tomatoes, potatoes, mango ($12): http://bit.ly/1R5ZKrb
A must order, the bhel puri was chockfull of bright and fresh flavors (spicy, sweet, tangy) with a satisfying variety of textures. It was purely addicting!

*Dahi Sev Puri: Semolina puffs, jaggery, mint chutney, yogurt, sev, cilantro ($13): http://bit.ly/21x20wx
It was love at first bite when I first had these from the DUM truck (only other place that offers it in the SF Peninsula area: http://bit.ly/1pqpE1K). Lots of textures and flavor profiles that explode in your mouth. It's hard to explain so you have to try it for yourself. However, I thought it was quite pricey compared to the DUM food truck. I know it's not fair to compare the prices to a food truck but DUM charges $3 for 3 pieces while it's $13 for 4 pieces at Indian Paradox. 

*Kanda Patata Poha: Flattened rice, onion, potato, turmeric, roasted peanuts ($11): http://bit.ly/1Uj1KCa
This was our least favorite dish. Not because it was bad but because the flavor was mute compared to the first two dishes and the overall texture was too mushy for our liking. 

The owner was a total sweetheart and you can tell she's really passionate about her love of wine (I overheard a convo she had with the table next to us). She was spread thin though since it was only her and the chef in the back. My only suggestion is to get larger water glasses. The water glasses were teeny weeny and held maybe 3.5-4 ounces of water (size of two shot glasses). I felt bad having to flag someone down to refill my glass since they were busy.

Indian Paradox is definitely recommended for a unique pre-dinner snack or nightcap. Get the Bhel Puri! I've been dreaming about that Mumbai roadside "crack" since my visit...
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
The food was alright but the wine was VERY GOOD. I never knew Indian chaat and wine could be paired together! Somehow, they work :)

The place is much smaller than I expected. It has a very cozy feel. The hostess is very friendly and pleasant. I would have given it a 3 just for the food. But decided to give it another star for the wine and the friendly hostess (and free desert when you check-in on Yelp).

I'd recommend going here if you are in the mood for some light snacks + drinks and just want to hangout with some friends.
author: Lasya B.

description:
Cute, small place (2 tables, 2 high tops, and a handful of bar seats) with elevated Indian street food. Two of us shared the masala peanuts, bhel puri (the best I've ever had with a bright finish from mango), dahi sev puri, and dabeli potato burgers, all with a great combination of spices. It was enough food for us, but voracious eaters might need something more substantial. A dessert has been added to the menu since the opening, and chai is coming.

Next time I'd like to grab a seat at the bar for a leisurely pre-dinner outing and have a light snack with its wine pairing to take advantage of the owner's sommelier background.
author: Cristina S.

description: Another gem! Really great Indian snacks and unexpectedly solid pairings. I say "unexpectedly" because Indian food is notoriously hard to pair wines with and the wines we tried here were underwhelming when sampled without the food. That said, each of the pairings worked SUPER well together! We'll definitely be back here to try more courses and surprising pairings :). Well done!!!
author: Nik T.

description:
Kavitha honestly made this experience even better than 5 stars, she's awesome. We ordered everything on the menu and can't rave enough about it. Kavitha knows her wines and made wonderful pairing recommendations. Happy hour is such a steal from 5-7 Tuesday Wednesday Thursday Sunday because most of the food is practically half price. 

Highly highly recommend
author: Deanna B.

description:
This is one of my most favorite places in SF now. Went with a friend for the first time this week and we loved it so much that we went there again.

Sometimes it takes a bit for the food to be prepared but it's totally worth the wait. I've tasted pretty much every vegetarian dish on the menu and loved almost everything but the Chai and the Poha are my favorites!

Also it's a treat to talk to Kavitha who's always smiling!
author: Amit R.

description:
I've been in the past in the evening for wine and chaat. I went today to try brunch. If you like Indian food and are frustrated that the menus of most Indian restaurants are so predictable then give this place a try. Tikka masala, biryani, etc. represent a minuscule portion of Indian cuisine! Give your taste buds a pleasant surprise and check out Indian Paradox which focuses on authentic Indian street food. For brunch, I tried the Egg Akuri and Chilli Cheese Toast.  (I may not need dinner). Both were tasty though the Chillie Cheese Toast was my favorite. A nice melding of flavors with a bit of kick from the chillie. I washed them down with lemongrass chai which was delicious. Brunch is a fairly new addition so it's still easy to get seated - it beats standing in line as is often the case with brunch places in the city. I'm looking forward to trying the rest of the menu. The food and value for money were great. I loved the playlist; it was almost song for song what I would have chosen myself. The owner is charming and passionate about introducing 'new' food to lovers of Indian cuisine. 

5 = will definitely go again; 4 = most likely will go again; 3 = may go again, but prefer not to; 2 = would only go if every other place was closed and I was starving; 1 = would see how long I could go without food.
author: A P.

description: I'll admit that I probably wasn't in the right mood at all when we came here after finding that the wait for Raggazza was going to be ridiculous. While the concept of an Indian snack food meal is interesting, it wasn't particularly appealing to me when we arrived. Although I liked trying all the dishes, I wasn't quite satisfied with the meal, and everything seemed to take forever.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Indian Paradox serves up a truly authentic Indian street food experience, successfully executing a perfect marriage between dishes that have been a staple of everyday Indian life, and unique and previously unheard of wines that have been hand picked to not only compliment the palette but also bring out the complex flavors in each dish. Add to that an intimate setting, with service that is personable, friendly and attentive, and prices that are reasonable, and all that elevates Indian Paradox from just another food and wine bar, to one that is refreshing and bold in its approach, yet familial and simple in its execution, rooted in the simple promise of providing people with a food and wine bar to get together and connect while savoring flavorful snacks and nurturing delicious wine. 

And for those of us from the "motherland"...Indian Paradox provides a slice of your mother's kitchen right in the middle of San Francisco. It does not get any better!

My husband and I were out on a rather wet and windy date night last night (we just adopted a puppy, so lets just say we desperately needed a date night away from parenting duties) and decided to drop in on a whim (my husband's whim and not mine and I'm the Indian and he's the American...how'se that for a "paradox"?) and two hours later we left overjoyed and satisfied to have experienced such great food and wine along with the most enriching conversations with the owner Kavitha. We tucked into the masala peanuts, the churmur, the bhel puri, the kanda batata poha, the shish kebab and the mishti doi and nurtured a wonderful bottle of the 2013 F. Thienpont Sauvignon Blanc Bordeaux. 

What completely caught me off guard was that even though everything was executed in a very simple yet tasteful manner, there was so much more of a story being told on the back end, from the myriad flavors in each dish to the perfectly paired wines to the manner in which every was served. It all immediately took me back home...home to India...to my mother's kitchen...to skipping school with my class mates and sitting on a sidewalk on a busy street eating snacks from the guy making the food on a rickshaw with a portable gas burner...remember that final scene from the movie Ratatouille when Anton Ego tastes the Ratatouille and is immediately transported back to his childhood to his mother's kitchen and he sheds a tear...that was me...last night...when I had my first bite...exquisite.

Unlike your usual low end (Naan n Curry) or high end (August 1five) Indian restaurant, Indian Paradox's focus is on small plates with a custom menu that is tailored specifically to Indian street food snacks that most people are not accustomed to knowing about (unless you are Indian, of course). If you are expecting naan or chicken tikka masala or matar paneer or biryani, that is not Indian Paradox. If you are curious about taking your curiosity for Indian food to the next level, if you are adventurous, if you are expecting simple, yet tasty and flavorful, small plate Indian street food snacks, paired with unusual wines, served in a setting that could very well make you feel like you are at a friend's kitchen, munching on snacks and drinking wine as you process your day, or catch up on your lives or just reconnect...THAT is Indian Paradox.

The opening of August 1 five and Babuji (both of which I also love) close to the same time Indian Paradox opened and the resulting hype surrounding the former two restaurants have overshadowed Indian Paradox, but perhaps in a way, that has also enabled it to stay "local", keep its neighborhood vibe alive and keep it personable and intimate, and also help it to understand its customer, its food and to continue experimenting to keep itself current and most important of all...stay true to its passion to cook and serve Indian street food the way it is cooked and served in India, where its just as much about the food and the wine as it is about people simply coming together to create memories.

Kavitha has a successful product in her hands and I cannot wait to see where else Indian Paradox will take San Francisco on its culinary journey of Indian street food and wine! Maybe one day brunch will be on the menu! My husband and I are a fan and we cannot wait to go back very soon with our families, friends and co workers...but let's keep Indian Paradox our little secret, ok?
author: Amit S.

description: What a hidden gem! Have been here twice for dinner and drinks with friends and will certainly be back. It's nice and cozy, but had no problem getting a table on the earlier side (though it quickly filled up). Food and service were fantastic. Go with a few friends and get a bunch of the small plates to share, everything we tried was lovely!
author: Ali S.

description:
Really awful food at ridiculous prices. Drab ambience, LED 'candles' everywhere, and a random bucket on top of the kitchen entrance. It's obvious that this is a low-budget high charge operation that lacks any thought towards interior design. Service is extremely slow... food took forever to arrive. Antithetical to street food, which is fast! But all that aside, the food really just was the singular sore point.

Nothing tastes like Indian street food or even Indian food. We ordered three things to see if we like anything enough to order more. We got: peanuts, churmur, and dabeli. Nice peanuts, flavourless blob of a mess churmur, and equally flavourless dabeli for $15. Literally boiled and mashed potatoes with almost no seasoning and missing every single garnish! So that's $7.50 per slider-sized sandwich... shockingly priced, especially for the quality. Not only did we not order anything else, we didn't want to take leftovers home either.

We tried this place because the idea of Indian street food paired with wine sounds exciting. But this is very poorly executed. Oh and we had the Greek red, which wasn't bad.
author: Mick J.

description:
This review is solely based on the food. I will say the  customer service experience was great.

This restaurant is super tiny. You can probably seat 8 at the bar, and there are 4 tables that can seat 2 (and maybe one table 3) persons at each.

I ordered the Dahi Sev Puri and  Kheema Pav. The potatoes in the puri super bland and so was the chutney. The Kheema was OK but the bread pairing did not go well because it was too flaky to eat with the kheema. 

I'd say if you want flavorful street food at a reasonable price then stick to Vik's in Berkeley. They know what's up.
author: ZEEBRA W.

description: We came in on Tuesday and tried the happy hour portions of the dahi sev puri, sundal, karbeli and shish kebab, with a wine pairing.  Everything was absolutely delicious.  Kavitha is charming, and explained all the dishes as she served us.
author: Mike H.

description: Very lovely pace. Good wine and amazing food. For people who like wine and cheese, this is a much better place than the normal wine bars! Best Indian street food in SF.
author: T G.

description:
Few weeks ago, we came to Indian Paradox with a couple of friend of ours who raves about this place! Our friends are a big wine connoisseurs and have a hard time finding wines that goes with Indian food, especially savory street food till they came to this place. 

This is truly a passion project  for the owner and she is very knowledgeable about the wines! She did a fantastic job recommending the wine with the snacks we ordered: Bhel and deconstructed pani puri! We really enjoyed this place! It's quiet different from traditional Indian food, as they only serve Indian street snacks. It's a great place to go for a date or with few friends! 

Such a quaint place with a unique Indian food experience and great wines!
author: P P.

description:
I've eaten here 4 times now and always love it. The concept is pairing wine with Indian street food - means it's a great place to go in a small group and share lots of dishes. Which is what we did on Saturday night before a show at the Independent.

I can't remember the dishes by name but we had Masala Penuts, a delicious garbanzo salad with raw mango, lentil pancakes with dip and two lamb dishes. Plus an amazing dish of chilled sauce and chutneys inside a puri which literally exploded with flavour in your mouth. Was plenty of food for five of us and with drinks only came to $30 each. And we were all raving about the different flavours.

The other thing is the owner/chef/sommelier is amazingly friendly and remembers us from previous visits. So it really feels homely.

For me, the biggest paradox of this place is why more people haven't discovered it. It's not Indian food as you know it but if you want a flavourful eating experience in a nice environment you should go there.
author: Diarmuid R.

description:
Perfect portions of delicious Indian street food. Also, a very nice host!

Do try the Dahi Sev Puri and the Mishti Doi. Ask for a pairing of wine.
author: Rajat T.

description: I found this place on yelp and took my  wife for our anniversary and she loved it !! Great ambiance for date night or get together. Got to taste their "Sundal" definitely the best I have ever had in Bay Area. Kavitha the Host was so pleasant and definitely she knew alot about the wines.
author: Balaji R.

description: Amazing food and service. Very creative. SF is full of great restaurants, and I enjoy them all. But Indian Paradox is a total gem. I highly recommend!
author: Gib S.

description:
Quaint little place that you will almost miss unless you keep an eye out for the name. We ordered Sundal and Bhel Puri along with the respective wine pairings. While the food was delicious, the wine pairing was good, not great. I would definitely come again for the food but I might skip the wine pairing the next time. 
Our server was very sweet and wonderful ! 

Good job with a new concept !
author: Vidya N.

description: Fun small place with great chaat and a great affordable happy hour and delicious wine. I had a great time here!
author: Andrew K.

description: Food was decent at best but for the price and wait it is not nearly worth it, you are better off finding an Indian food truck and saving the money and time. If I could leave no star I would. Dry and flavorless food.
author: Luke D.

description: Another visit and another great experience. Food's consistently good and fresh. There's nothing  that gets close to freshly prepared chaat!
author: Namrata J.

description: Too often Indian food in American restaurants is greasy and lacks distinct flavor between dishes. Indian paradox's food was all so tasty, spicy, and flavor-forward. For those of you unfamiliar with the depth and variety of India's regional cuisines, you should check it out. It's a small restaurant, but 7 of us dominated the u-shaped bar and could easily chat and share plates. We tried everything on the menu, save for dessert (Powder is next door, so we had to go there!) The prices were also super reasonable given the high quality and location in SF, which was an added treat! They feature a lot of chaat, or Indian street foods, and smaller dishes. They also had a great wine selection; my guess is that the "paradox" of this whole in the wall place is that they have Indian food with wine pairings. I will definitely be back for my next date night!
author: R D.

description:
We are staying in Lower Haight and came by on our first night. We are fans of Indian food, so we were not expecting anything new, but this food is different than your standard Indian fare - and even better!

We had the bhel puri, kanda batata poha, and adai. It all had such a vibrant and unique flavor and was plenty for the two of us (with a bottle of wine). We loved it all. 

We sat at the bar and chatted with the lovely owner. The food is all made fresh, so plan to spend some time here, but the ambiance is nice for a night out and the food is well worth the wait.
author: Lyndsey L.

description: My boyfriend and I had a wonderful dinner here last Friday night. We live nearby and stopped by expecting a wait, but grabbed a table near the window right away. The food and wine were both delicious (the sundal was a standout), but our favorite part was interacting with the owner, who was warm, fun, and very sweet. We will certainly be back!
author: Kate C.

description:
Perfect for dates or groups of friends! The space is perfect for catching up and relaxing . Happy hour is great. 
We got the vegetarian sampler and the kebab. Very flavorful. Fun to explore. They are small plates so you'd have to reorder a few if you expect to get a very full. The wine selection was not too overwhelming and the owner provided top recommendations (I really liked the zinfandel)
I hope this place continues to do well! I feel the neighbors especially yoga garden would LOVE this place! Can't wait to be back!
author: Josephine L.

description: We tried this place during SF restaurant week and loved it! I got to try almost everything on the menu, and each dish was so good. I loved speaking with the owner about her journey to open a restaurant, and her passion comes through in the unique and delicious food that she serves. The wine pairings are unconventional but only added to the meal. I can't wait to go back!
author: Lauran K.

description:
Kevitha is the BEST. Her chef is the best. Those recipes are amazing and leave you so full. 
Sundal is my favorite. I go back every time for just that - garbanzo beans with mustard seeds, curry leaves, coconut shreds and tiny squares of mango. YUM I just had some and I already want more!
author: Edna M.

description: Great place for some wine and bar food. Unique Indian cuisine not easily found elsewhere- will definitely be back
author: Siberius J.

description: Absolutely loved this place. They have many nice vegetarian options.
author: Vishal C.

description: Awesome Indian food and great wine pairing. Will be back soon. Nice addition to the neighborhood.
author: Teresa M.

description:
This place needs to improve on many things,
1) we walked by looking for a place, the open a google map to locate and walked backward, put a good sign
2) we were the only ppl there, there is no tv nothing to pass the time
3) now food, we orders sev puri, it was good but def not worth for $13...it's exp place but not  like high standard ambiance and food
4) we ordered dabeli, sauce has no flavor and they didn't put any tamarind sauce either, it was dry and potatoes were old, if u serve potatos, at least make tikki out of it
5) mistidoi, dessert, must say it was good...good amount of sugar but no flavor of pistachio, put pistachio inside too, not just as little topping


Suggestion
1) make a good sign outside
2) have a good ambiance
3) don't laugh when customer is taking ur food picture 
3) have appetizers different section than main course
4) expensive, lower ur price...put it based on ur food quality ( you can easily lower to $3 to $5 on each dishes)
5) there is a reason why there are only 44 reviews on yelp even though they are open for last 6 months
6) heat up food, it was so cold and sauces are tasteless


I will give 3 stars just because I went there for mistidoi, and it was okay, also I hope they take this suggestion seriously.
author: Minal G.

description: We're new to the neighborhood and after a really lovely dinner this evening have marked Indian Paradox as a go-to spot. The South Indian food is readily vegan or veganizable (good for a mixed omnivore-vegan couple) and the quality is as good or better than our favorite South Indian restaurants in Manhattan. The space is on the smaller side which lends to a nice ambiance that is magnified by friendly and attentive service.
author: Carson C.

description: Worth the hype! Loved all the food we ordered. Icing on the cake was the mishti doi. I have grown up having it in my childhood, and this one completely lived up to my expectations!!
author: Vidya M.

description:
I liked the Poha. I really did. I really want to go again and try something else. The catch? Any reasonable person with a moderate appetite would need at least two servings of the Poha to be satiated. But at $10 each, I would have to spend $20 for a basic meal of onions, potatoes, and rice (ok, it also has a few peanuts thrown in - and the rice is indeed gloriously FLATTENED -  should we call this dish artisanal then?). This makes no sense whatsoever, and I can't rationalize no matter how hard I try (did I mention that I really liked the Poha?). Oh, the agony!

According to the informational blurb on the website, the paradox is that "Indian cuisine (especially Indian street food) unlike, say the French cuisine is not what you associate with fine dining, and the whole charade that comes with it. And wine on the contrary, is all about etiquette, a certain presentation style, behavior and tasting manners that sometimes borders on a snobbish attitude for some." 

But wait, what really is the paradox here? The paradox is charging $10 for a small serving of Indian street food traditionally known to be very affordable. Now that's a fitting paradox!
author: H R.

description: I'm so sad to be only giving Indian Paradox 3 stars because I was eagerly waiting for it to open and upon trying it was very disappointed. I am a bit conflicted because while this place is one of the few Indian restaurants that serve chaat (Indian street food), it's ridiculously expensive. I wouldn't mind paying an arm and a leg for chaat if at least the portions were a little larger. But these plates were meant for maybe a light snack before a real meal. The whole wine pairing thing is kind of interesting but not my thing. Maybe I'm a purist, but chaat does not really taste great with wine? The service was great and quick, can't complain about the flavors either, but definitely won't be going back to spend 20 dollars on mediocre chaat.
author: Shruti S.

description:
I'm usually very harsh on Indian street food in my reviews, but hats off to Kavitha for creating delectable bar bites that are true to the street cuisine in Indian. And yet, she has managed to find wines that pair well with the food ... which is definitely a challenge with Indian food.

Loved the dabeli, churmur and keema pav. Loved the wine pairings. Good portions.

Also, being Indian, loved the bollywood music :)
author: Ankur V.

description: Kavitha puts her heart and soul into Indian Paradox - and it shows! She has created a wonderful, small restaurant full of charm and good energy. If you want a taste of Southern Indian street food (Chennai), this is the place! I'm half Indian and the food here reminds me of my travels to India with my family.  The wine is delicious and the sundal, masala peanuts, adai and dabeli burger are my absolute favorites. But, no review would be complete without mentioning mishti doi - the most delicious mango dessert on the planet!
author: Guvnors M.

description: Amazing food, ambience and wine. Great place to just relax and eat small bites. We had bhel, the yogurt dessert and many other small portions - you can't go wrong. To top it all, they were playing great music including some classic old Bollywood songs. Just perfect for a rainy SF night :-)
author: Vasudha M.

description:
The concept of this place gets 5 stars itself in my mind! I love the idea of having a indian tapas restaurant with creative dishes and a nice cozy ambiance! 

This place had been on my bookmarks since the day it opened and I finally had a chance to try it on a Thursday evening. The restaurant is very tiny with only 4 tables and then bar seating. Even on a Thursday, it was packed! 

We ordered some glasses of wine (don't really remember the names) and a couple of dishes to accompany them. My favorites:
Churmur - this is basically a deconstructed pani puri dish but a bite of this tastes exactly like eating a pani puri! I loved the concept and the execution was excellent! 

Kanda batata poha - awesome, light dish served with a tasty chutney that really enhances the flavors of this dish. 

Dabeli - basically like an indian slider! The patties were very tasty and they had a bit of a spicy kick which made them even better! Definitely the most filling out of all the dishes!

I would say that this place is definitely expensive for the quantity of food you get, but it's definitely worth the try because the food is delicious!
author: Malika R.

description:
Living just 3 blocks from this restaurant, I was shocked to only recently discover its existence on Yelp. Apparently it's been open for a couple months, but their lack of signage in the window or over the door makes it very easy to miss.

Anyway, the menu is a very reasonable selection of non-typical Indian dishes, each with a recommended wine pairing (my friend and I skipped the wine, but apparently the proprietor (Kavitha) is herself a major wine aficionado). 

The food is fairly priced, and the flavors and textures are a bit more creative than your usual Indian restaurant at comparable prices. 

The dishwater and copper vessels were also a nice touch.

It's great to see someone pursuing a dream, and I hope Kavitha keeps this place going--I'll definitely be back!
author: David Z.

description: So you walk inside, and if you have any inmate strategy running through your veins, you immediately order a beer or a glass of champagne (which is actually quite nice). And then we decided to relax and let the owner take over. Everything is outstanding. Everything. Extremely Vegetarian Friendly.  Unassumingly fantastic. Spices are very well balanced.
author: Chris B.

description:
What a wonderful new addition to Divisadero!

I rarely get the super personal, I-made-this-lovingly-for-you feeling at new SF restaurants anymore. We were chatted up by the girl manning the bar, who was very cool and made us feel welcome along with offering good wine suggestions as well as multiple tastes. The woman who served us our food brought each out one at a time, and talked us through each dish, where it hails from and best way to eat it. You can tell she really cares about the food, and she's just as excited to give it to us as we were to eat it.

The food itself was fantastic and fun to eat. Two of us split (and recommend) the:

* Bhel Puri: This was a fun cone of delicious textures. As one can expect from great indian food, the flavors are intricate and balanced. Crunchy, herbal, savory and sweet... I could have eaten this all night.

* Dahi Sev Puri: Make sure you listen to her when she says eat it all at once. I somehow still managed to make a mess, but I was fairly warned. This is a crunchy pocket that explodes with yogurt goodness.

* Shish Kebab: Expertly cooked lamb with a lovely simple chutney. This balanced the meal out well. Presented so nicely in the little cast iron skillet, I liked it ebfore I even tasted it.

I can't wait to come back and try the rest of the menu!
author: Haley J.

description:
I had the pleasure of getting dinner here with a friend on a Sunday night and what a pleasant surprise this little gem was. We had two dishes: the Kanda Batata Poha rice & Dabeli. Both dishes were so flavorful. I loved the combination of spices in both dishes. The seasoned potatoes combined with roasted peanuts with pretty mouth watering. I was telling my friend who was with me that I wish I could cook like this.

We also had a very nice chat with the owner and really appreciated her passion for her business. Whenever I visit San Francisco, this will be one of my go to places.
author: Erik M.

description: The owner was so sweet and helpful but that won't get you five stars, that comes from the food! Delicious! Indian street food that made for a scrumptious snack or light meal. The warm chick peas were amazing g, who knew chick peas could be so tasty. As was the udihpi, I think that's what it was, it was a cone filled with flavorful yummy crunchy treats.
author: Monica R.

description:
Wine bar + Indian street food = a total Indian paradox. A completely unexpected and perfectly chill spot tucked in at Divis and Haight. 
The wine list is small but legit, and the food is nothing like you'd expect. Don't come here craving chicken tikka masala. Instead, just go with the flow and try a little of everything. It's a really tasty mix of texture and flavors that will have you trying to decipher every bite. Go with it!
The owners are in the kitchen and will bring the food oit and describe it with pride and passion. 
The price is right and you'll leave full and happy. 
I'm so glad this spot popped up in the neighborhood. I'll be back soon!
author: Olivia R.

description:
Sweet small warm (Desi) Wine bar !!

Good selections of Indian small appetizers. And gracefully designed wine and food menu. Masala peanuts reminds me Chakana.
author: Saurabh M.

description:
I'm a big fan of Indian street food and the quality of the food here is very good.  I feel the wine pricing is fair if a little light on the pour; it's a well-curated list and the wine I tried was my favorite glass at a restaurant in a while.

It's quite obvious that the owner has a very good palate for wine and this type of cuisine but in terms of pricing I just can't suggest this place. I think similar street food dishes at Dosa on Filmore are every bit as good and either less expensive or significantly larger portions. Having a satisfying meal here would require spending much more money than I'd feel comfortable with on what is at it's heart peasant food. I hope the owner finds the right balance as they are obviously talented.
author: Justin P.

description: What a delightful meal! Everything we ordered was delicious. The coconut chutney that came with the Adai was absolutely unbelievable. We ordered a bottle of the pairing wine which was also very good. Our waitress (who also seemed like the hostess) was pleasant and helpful. Overall, a fun and reasonably priced date night option.
author: Nikki B.

description:
Simply love this place - just so disappointed it took almost a year of being open to find this lil' gem just a few blocks from my house.  It is perfect for a happy hour glass of vino and snack with a friend or romantic date night w/ your special someone.  

My wife is Indian and is a wonderful cook (and only uses spices direct from India) so I'm always looking for a genuinely authentic Indian meal out.  I was drawn by the name and the pairing of wines w/ an assortment of menu options from all corners of India. 

My favorite go-to is the Sundal.  Just a crisp starter - warm garbanzo beans w/ shaved coconut, mustard seeds, curry leaves and bits of mango.  I love the Dabeli, which are a couple of potato burger sliders that just explode w/ texture and flavor as they're topped w/ a tamarind date chutney, peanuts and pomegranate.  I would also recommend the Kheema Pav, minced lamb braised with tomato, chilies and spices as well as the lamb shish kabob. 

Kavitha & her staff couldn't be more welcoming and love to share the stories behind the food and wine selections.  Very helpful w/ menu options for my wife who is vegan and gluten-free as well.  Guarantee you will find at least one item that will pull you back within a week.  You will not be disappointed.
author: Wes E.

description: Incredibly unique. We had the vegetarian sampler with the reccomended wine pairing. It was unexpected and absolutely delicious. The owner was very friendly and helpful. Great happy hour!
author: Annelies S.

description:
Mouth-watering authentic Indian street food taken to the next level. Paired perfectly with local and international wines (hence, the paradox.. street food + wine has never been done before!). You can't make this at home, and you won't find it anywhere else in SF (I've tried!!)

Delectable, prepared impeccably, and full of passion and flavor. Better than being in India because of the chill yet classy vibe of this cozy, colorful corner in the lower haight. Perfect for both foodies and winos.

We tried nearly everything on the menu. Our favorites were the Bhel puri, Dahi sev puri, Churmur, Peanuts, Dabeli, and the Lamb Shish Kabab.. packed with flavor and so, so delicious!!! Left us with cravings for days. Will be back again and again!!
author: Nikki H.

description:
my friend has been eyeing this place for a while, so we finally made our way here today.  we came around 430, and they had just opened.  happy hour starts at 5, including on sundays, and you get to try all the chaat for a very good price.  

3 of us shared the veg platter, the dabeli (veg burger), the poha and the deconstructed pani puri (forgot the name).  we washed all this down w/ a bottle of cab franc, which the owner kavita (sp?) recommended.  everything was delicious.  i love the south indian flavors of everything, which is a lot more refined and lighter than your typical indian restaurant food.  by the time we finished, the restaurant was pretty crowded.  come early for snacks if you want to snag a seat!
author: Helen T.

description:
Original street food, tasty from small bites to full plate. The presumed owner/chef came out of her kitchen to check on us before and after the meal.
I would recommend this wine/ eatery if you are in the neighborhood.
author: D T.

description: What's the Paradox? Spectacular Chaat, an amazing little wine list that provocatively challenges ones assumptions about wine and dal. But having food and wine of this caliber at these prices is astounding. I know that there are lots of "new" Indian spots opening, but I have been there, and here is the real deal, and what a deal
author: Larry B.

description:
It's a very small place, with maybe two tables, two bar tables, and the bar. There also seems to only be about 2 people working here, but service is great with the owner coming out to make sure we liked everything and the waitress who helped us was very generous with her pours :) and gave tastings!

It's interesting to pair wine with Indian food, but I will have to say that I'm a fan of the pinot + potato burger!

We also had the garbanzo salad - which was good and the deconstructed pani puri [tbh, not my favorite]. I'd definitely recommend coming here just for a snack and some wine and good conversation.
author: Christina C.

description:
Came here for the first time Friday night with some friends and it's was little busy but four bar stools was waiting for us and the night begun! We meet Kavitha ( owner ) sweet and sassy, but in amazing away ! She warmed us up with her personality and great smile and started to suggest few items for us. She has an amazing wine selection but couple of us wanted a beer.  She pulled out from the fridge an amazing big bottle of German beer that was fantastic . Then we had couple of small dishes she suggested, for starters...MASALA PEANUTS, toasted peanuts tossed with ghee, lemon juice and Garam masala served warm..perfect with the beer! 

***** five stars 
BHEL PURI
Crispy crackers and puffed rice mixed with jaggery and mint chutneys, tomatoes, potatoes, and mango served in a cone . 

This was so freaking awesome we had to order a second helping and then suggested the next few guests sitting by us they should order the same. I told them if they didn't think this was amazing I would buy it !

A definite fave in our books and highly recommend it!!
author: Michael F.

description: This place is really cute and the food is delicious.  The portions are a little small, but it's really high quality, yummy food.  I'll be back again and again.  My favorite dish tonight was the Sundal.  I could eat a whole bucket of it!
author: Ryan L.

description:
Bhel puri and deconstructed paani puri very fantastic and very well made with high quality ingredients

The Adai was sort of bland and wouldn't recommend..but may be its how the dish is supposed to taste
author: Samir K.

description: The place is tiny, and it was really crowded when we went. But we didn't have to wait for more than 15 minutes. However, the place looked severely understaffed with very slow service. The place mostly serves chat, and not real entrees. The bhel puri was really good, dahi sev puri and poha were strictly okay. The place is pricey and if you plan to have dinner, plan on spending upwards of $30 per person.
author: Trushna K.

description: I have no problem with the quality of the food.   But the prices are truly outrageous. The dahi batata puri for example is priced at $13. The same item at Viks Chaat out in Berkely goes for $5.75. Interesting concept to pair chaat and wine together but tough to accept burning the wallet on low cost street food.
author: Arzan R.

description: If you're tired of the same predictable menu in Indian restaurants,  this place is for you!  Really inventive menu, wine pairings and incredibly reasonable prices made us fall in love the first night. The lamb was amazing. Great service.
author: Ed T.

description: Came here at 8pm on a Thursday. The wait time for this place was very long for the food (we ordered three dishes) to come out. The food was alright, I feel like the flavors and textures didn't really come together for me. We waited over 40 mins for Bhel sev puri, (which was a cold dish), adai, and kanda batata poha. I totally understand everything is made to order and fresh, but I wasn't expecting a 40min wait after we sat down and ordered. I also got kind of erked the waiter kept spilling water on my pants everytime he refilled our water glasses because there was a leak in the pitcher.  That's not really his fault. I also heard it was also his first day. So that's understandable. Also, the place is small and it's hard to move...like at all.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
This place is amazing!!!! Anyone who says it's not worth the price doesn't understand how spoiled we are to have a place like this. Not only does the owner/chef have an superb pallet, her wine parings are too perfect to be true! Try the SHISH KEBAB (lamb) with the MALA VIDA red blend, one of my new favorites which you can not find anywhere else in SF. Also must try the 
DAHI SEV PURI, I almost cried it was so good. This place is highly recommended! Thank you Indian Paradox!
author: Anna M.

description: This place is so inviting! The food is so awesome with amazing pairing with wine! Some of the dishes that are a must try include - 1. Sundal, 2. Masala Peanuts, 3. Bhel Puri and the yummy dessert- Misti Doi. The owner- Kavitha has an extensive knowledge about the wine pairings and I think she has done her homework so well! Kudos! This is like a go to place for me with the amazing combination of Indian Street Food & Wine! Definitely recommend this place for Indian food and wine lovers.
author: Jay S.

description:
This is a good restaurant if you are looking for good wine paired with some very flavorful, light and unique cuisine.  Think of it as Indian tapas. However, I wouldn't recommend coming here if you are really hungry, or on a budget.  

I started with the $4 bowl of nuts which were deliciously seasoned with turmeric, amongst other spices.  Next were the pastry puffs filled with yogurt, cilantro and green sauce which we were told to eat 'all at once' with our hands.  They provided a burst of fresh flavors that exploded in my mouth. I was left wanting more.  

Next, I ordered the veggie burger.  This was unlike any I have ever had.  It was spicy, yet also tangy from fresh pomegranates, and had an interesting texture from nuts and beans mixed together.  The veggie burger itself was one of the best I have ever had, but I was disappointed it was served between a couple of cheap, dry dinner rolls. I also felt felt the price ($18) it should have come with some sort of side (a salad of some sort, pickles, maybe some curried potatoes or veggies?). For 2 people sharing a few plates of food and a couple glasses of wine expect your bill to be at least $100.

Overall, the chef here is very talented and unique but I think to gain repeat business they will need to either lower their prices or add more value to the entrees and improve on the bread and some of the ingredients.  I went during peak dinner time and the restaurant was empty the whole time. As it stands now, this is a place worth trying once as a very unique abstraction to the same old cuisine, but probably not one you'd frequent often, unless of course you have a lot of money to burn.
author: Daniel K.

description: Cute little place with nice Indian street food selection. We loved the Dahi puri and the lamb keema! Yum! The owner is so friendly and great to chat with.  Love the idea of pairing wine with Indian foods.  You don't see that often.
author: Jessica J.

description: The wait here was atrocious. The food was very sub par for the price. This feels like the epitome of what one should avoid in a restaurant.
author: Michael H.

description: This is a hidden treasure. Very authentic food. Sundal was a highlight here, don't miss it. I would come back here many more times!
author: Rajagopal S.

description: About time for a desi hipster place! Legit Indian snacks all made from scratch. No 6.99 buffet crap for cheapsters. Adai was good, but churmur took me back home. Of course a bottle of mala vida helped.
author: Vijay B.

description: Food was not spicy or impressive. The wine pairing was not too fruity..I think of the food had been spicier then the pairing could of worked. My friend is from India and was not impressed.
author: A J.

description:
Food was tasty but not even close to justifying the prices for what they're charging. There were 2 of us late on Saturday night when the restaurant was at 3/4 capacity at the most. We ordered 3 small dishes to share and it took over 30 minutes for the first dish to come out, 20 more minutes for the 2nd dish and another 20 minutes for the third dish. Keep in mind these are basically appetizer size dishes and it took over an hour for all our dishes to come. I can't imagine how it would be had the restaurant had actually been busy. 

On top of that, for 4 glasses of their basic wine and rosé, with 3 side dishes essentially (2 were vegetarian) it was over $100 with tax and tip. Pretty outrageous prices.
author: Tom F.

description: Completely blown away by the Chaat (Indian Street food) here! I'm very picky about chaat and this bars even some of the authentic offerings in South Bay! The suggested wine pairings were a perfect match and I even found a new dessert wine that I loved. Strong recommendation for anyone who enjoys spice and red wine.
author: Sandhya S.

description: As an Indian-American who grew up going to India regularly, I vouch for this place. Indian Paradox and its passionate, knowledgeable and feisty owner, Kavita, are taking on an underrepresented genre of Indian cuisine: street food. And they're executing it deliciously. You're not going to find your average (read: mediocre) chicken tikka masala here. You'll be challenged to try dishes you probably haven't heard of, and you'll be pleasantly surprised at the delightful mix of salty, sweet, spicy, sour, and crunchy elements. That's the joy of Indian chaat. The food is so tasty that I'm excited to bring my food snob parentals here. And add in thoughtful wine pairings? Get out of here. It's awesome. Actually don't go, I don't want it getting too crowded. :-P
author: Simi D.

description: Dingy place, small chairs, and very small servings for premium prices.
author: Vivek P.

description: Awesomeee Sundal!! I haven't had such delicious Sundal even in India ;) and the wine they paired up with (karavitskis) was really good . The food and the music was an absolute delight.
author: Rekha S.

description: Such a cute little place with delicious food! When I want Indian I always default to two places in San Francisco and I'm so excited to now add Indian Paradox to my list. The menu is a refreshing change with a lot of items you never see at a restaurant (like potato poha!). I tried pretty much every veggie dish on the menu and they were all amazing. Will definitely be coming back for more!
author: Mansi S.

description: Great concept to pair wine with Indian food. The menu doesn't offer a whole lot but a few items that can be considered Indian street food. They have items from pretty much all parts of India. Good quality is good, owner is super nice. The place is small and does tend to get packed during weekend.
author: S Krishna S.

description:
Let me be upfront and start with the fact that I used to work with Kavitha.  She was one of the engineers at my company and left a few months ago to pursue her dream.  I knew that Kavitha was knowledgeable about food and wine.  She'd had a few pop-ups in the city, but I was never able to make it to one of them.  
I finally stopped by Indian Paradox yesterday and was really impressed.  She doesn't have a sign up yet, but it's not hard to find with your trusty map app.  It's right next door to Bus Stop Pizza.  And no problems finding a parking spot.
First off, I loved the interior.  Colors are great and the space is warm and inviting.  The Indian movie posters and votives are a nice addition.  Fun Indian background music.  And I don't say this often, but her bathroom smells great ;).
Kavitha is very warm and welcoming and the food is amazing.  The flavors and textures are fresh, colorful and unique.  I've never had anything quite like it.  She has a very interesting wine collection and I loved the whites including a wonderful Vinho Verde - brighter and less mineral than the ones I've had in the past.  
I loved everything we had.  I was saddened that we had dinner reservations as I would really like to try the lamb - next time! 
Stop by for a memorable experience.  Once you try it, you'll be back.
author: Stephanie E.

description: This little spot dishes out big flavors.  Everything served wasn't anything I've ever had before.  We began with Street Snacks and went through to Platters.  Not one dish disappointed.  I don't eat lamb, but I will eat the Shish Kabab over and over til I'm blue in the face.  Hats off to the Chef and God bless the owner for the courage and bravery it takes to compete in a City full of intense culinary magic.  I'll be back as long as you hold the door open.  I'm sure it was their pleasure to serve, but it is my honor to eat here.  Bravo!
author: D C.

description: I liked poha, mishti doi,  and dabeli at this place. They have a very good suggestions of wines for every item they have on their list. Suggested wines realy goes well with the food. I recommend this place for every wine and Indian food lover.
author: Ankit D.

description: From the moment you walk in the door, the delicious smell of the Indian food assures you that you are in for a treat. The spicy street food really does pair well with the expertly curated wine. On a rainy Thursday night the vibe was simultaneously lively and cozy. The deliciousness of the food and wine is matched by the graciousness of the service. They are excited about their wines and they want you to learn and appreciate them as much as possible.  The portions are hearty enough to make IP a dinner destination, not just snacks.   It's hard to resist ordering more as you enjoy the food and wine.  A very unique wine bar concept that is executed well.
author: Troy S.

description: Very good food, although the portions are a bit small. The service is also slow, especially if the place is busy. I'm really, really cheering for this business to make it, as it's wonderful for happy hour.
author: Liz R.

description: The food, the concept of pairing wine with Indian street food absolutely is amazing! We totally enjoyed our time here with yummy food and wine! The "sundal" & "Bhel Puri" deserve a special mention. Do check this place out!
author: Jay S.

description: What a gem we have on Divisadero! This in not your typical curry place. In fact, not a single dish has a curry sauce. I highly recommend you order the food with the wine pairing. Every dish is lovingly prepared and the wine carefully selected. I have had every dish on the menu a few times and I'm still blown away! Lots of great Vegetarian/Vegan options. The lamb is amazing if you need meat, especially with the Mala Vida wine.
author: Monica L.

description: I brought a group of friends here for a birthday celebration.  We were treated to an evening of well curated Indian street food and wine perfectly paired to go with it.  Kavitha was incredibly warm, and welcoming to our group.  We were guided in the right direction when it came to wine choices.  The favorite dish at the table was Dahi Sev Puri, the flavors actually explode in your mouth.
author: Natalie C.

description:
Really cool new spot in the up and coming Divisadero corridor. Being a lover of all types of Indian food I knew I needed to try this place out when I heard it had opened. 

You can tell great care went into the crafting of the menu as most of the items are paired with a wine to match. The set up is very cozy, working best for a casual date spot or somewhere to grab something quick before going out for drinks. I had the sundal which had a great flavor combination of savory and citrus from the fresh mango. The owner does a great job of making you feel welcome and answering any questions you may have.

Definitely recommend this new restaurant!
author: Ryan G.

description: The food is exquisitely delicate with amazing taste!  The personal heart in the preparation by the Chef Owner,  Kavita, is generous! A simple environment seems an appropriate backdrop to a gourmet presentation of Indian Street Faire!  Yummy!
author: Edward E.

description: I love this place. Kavitha's energy is really what makes this place great - she's so sweet and she fills the place with love. She also really knows her wine - she makes great selections and is very knowledgable. Overall a very warm and welcoming ambience, combined with great wine and great food in a great location. I'll be coming back soon!
author: Trini L.

description: Food is fine and delicious. The wine selection is Ok. Service is top-notch but price is way too high for the quantity..
author: Margaux M.

description:
Returned to order the "rest of the menu" that i didn't get a chance to order on my first visit

The only issue is that I can't give it 6 stars.

Great
author: S K.

description: Excellent food, amazing service and wine recommendations!  Bhel Puri was fantastic. Will definitely be back!
author: David G.

description: I don't often do reviews but I had to review this place. The owner, Kavita, was there and an incredible host. Food was delicious and satisfying! Will definitely return!
author: Varin G.

description: Seriously, my favorite indian restaurant in the city. And the wine is legit. 3rd time here. Will keep coming back. Owner is a doll!!!
author: Gernaut A.

description: I recently tried this new neighborhood spot, which serves Indian street food, consisting of small plates of mostly vegetarian dishes.  The food is delicious, with lots of bold flavors.  It is different from the mostly North Indian food that we are generally exposed to in the U.S.  The atmosphere is also nice -- casual, friendly, and the woman working behind the bar and taking all the orders is very attentive and friendly.  They also have a small but good list of wine and beer that complements the food nicely.  I will definitely go back.
author: Tony S.

description: Came here Saturday night and had an incredible experience. Sat at the bar and the wine, food and conversation with the owner and chef were so memorable. The two of us ended up ordering 2 lamb kabobs because they were that good. Cannot wait to come back! Trust me, it is very worth it!
author: Kristen H.

description: Perfect neighboorhood spot with fresh, fragrant bites and great wine!
author: Nikki A.

description: Love having a REAL wine bar in my neighborhood! What a lovely paradox indeed. The owner, who is a sommelier btw, not only has exquisite Indian bites but has created a wine list to die for. The wine menu is not super long but has someone for everyone and those "somethings" are so delicious. Perfect for date night or night out with friends.
author: Katie S.

description: The food here is amazing. You won't find anything like it in the city. And the owner is so customer oriented- she comes out and explains the story of each dish. I'd highly recommend trying it out.
author: Michael T.

description: Great new spot on Divis! Good Indian tapas/street food our favorite was the pani puri dish! The owner Kavita was really sweet. The only downside is that it's very small but the tables seemed to turnover fast.
author: Jody M.

description: Came here with some buddies a couple of days ago and basically ordered the entire menu (almost!). Overall I'd give this place a solid 4 stars - I was happy to see that as the evening progressed the place got busy (always love to see smbs succeed!!). Starting from the top the first several items were strong 4-5 stars with the Sundal, Churmur and Bhel Puri being stand outs. From there on out for us the items began to plateau except for the Poha which was also a 4-5 star dish. Of everything we ate, the kebabs were the weakest - the flavors weren't what we felt they should've been - too heavy on the coriander seeds which over-powered the dish. The mishti-doi dessert was also a solid 4-5 stars. The owner Kavita came by several times to see how we were doing and we all felt she was an excellent host. I would gladly return and try the last few remaining items that we didn't.
author: Anon Y.

description: We ordered three street snacks and all were very tasty and unique from any Indian food I've had in SF, however for the portion size, I think the prices are way too high. It also took nearly 30' for each snack to come out on a weekday night that wasn't  terribly busy, making our dinner last almost two hours in total. I won't return considering the extremely slow service and well over $100 bill (including tax and tip) for two people to have a very light dinner with two glasses of wine.
author: Chris W.

description: food very tasty but for the quantity they give you this place is way overpriced. either cut the prices by 50% or double the portions
author: gautam m.
